node.title: 'Relax on demand': What a freediver and a yoga teacher know about breathing
node.alt: An Asian woman with red lipstick and a grey coat takes a deep breath in through her nose.
node.description: Breathing is instinctual but that doesn't mean it can't be improved. Using different techniques for different types of exercise can impact your performance and daily life.
node.content:
["Breathing is something we all do without thinking.", "But have you ever considered how to get the most out of each breath?", "Tony Blazevich, professor of biomechanics and director of the Centre for Exercise and Sports Science Research\u00a0at Edith Cowan University, explains the process that occurs when we breathe.", "Oxygen enters our lungs and then our blood stream, which fuels our muscles and organs.", "", "
Tony Blazevich says athletes can use different breathing techniques\u00a0to get the most out of their performance.(Supplied)
", "\"Your brain requires a huge amount of oxygen, your heart requires oxygen, and just about every process you need to do every day at some point will need oxygen because that's the only way we can get energy,\" Professor Blazevich\u00a0tells ABC RN's Sporty.", "Regular breathing involves up to 16 breaths a minute when you're not thinking about it, he says, but there are many techniques to change your breathing.", "Taking shallow breaths, on the other hand,\u00a0can make it difficult to get sufficiently oxygenated air into the blood, which isn't ideal for sports or for daily life.", "
Breathing while exercising
", "Different types of exercise can require\u00a0different breathing techniques.", "For instance, during swimming we should breathe in through the mouth and out through the nose, Professor Blazevich says.\u00a0", "\"We only have a very short period of time to breathe in. So we normally breathe in through the mouth because a larger volume of air can be inhaled in the short time available,\" he says.", "\"While many swimmers also breathe out through the mouth \u2026. most good swimmers breathe out slowly through the nose whilst underwater, especially in the freestyle technique.\"", "Professor Blazevich\u00a0says this is a better way of breathing while swimming.", "\"It's ideal to slowly release air [through the nose] because that takes carbon dioxide away ... [and] it helps to control breathing rate and thus helps with relaxation during swimming,\" he explains.", "By contrast, when running, he says we should take shorter breaths to sync our breathing with our stride pattern.", "\"When we land on the ground, we want to be breathing out, so we will time our breathing when we run, to make sure it matches our stride.", "\"If you're really tired, you'll double your breathing [but] if you're feeling okay, you'll halve it so it's always in sync with your stride.\"", "Professor Blazevich\u00a0says that often when people exercise, they hold their breath, but\u00a0it\u2019s important to\u00a0remember to breathe out as well as breathe in, particularly in a gym context or if you\u2019re an older person.", "\"If you take a nice deep breath\u00a0and then hold it, your blood pressure goes up. And of course, if blood pressure goes up, we're at a greater risk of things like a heart attack, or a stroke or some other complications,\" he says.", "
'Relax on demand'
", "", "
Stig Severinsen has set world records by holding his breath underwater.(Supplied:\u00a0Casper Tybjerg)
", "Sometimes, however, holding your breath is a beneficial thing to do.", "Stig Severinsen, four-time world freediving champion and author of Breatheology, The Art of Conscious Breathing, was the first person in the world to hold his breath for more than 20 minutes.", "And he says it's taught him the secret to relaxation.", "", "
Stig\u00a0Severinsen is a Danish freediver who began holding his breath in his family pool as a child.\u00a0(Supplied:\u00a0Casper Tybjerg)
", "The freediver has explored the possibilities of breathwork for himself\u00a0and for those he's training, which has included Olympic swimmers and Danish and US navy seals.", "\"I use my freediving as a way of advocating for all the benefits of breath holding,\" he says.", "But \"never hold your breath\u00a0alone in water\", he adds.", "\"That's the first rule of free diving. It can feel so wonderful that actually you don't want to stop and you push a little bit too much. And you can unfortunately have what's called a blackout. So you lose consciousness and then you [could] drown.\"", "
Unlearning bad habits
", "Sarasvati Dawson has been teaching yoga for more than 20 years.", "She says breathing is key in yoga because it helps to slow down a busy mind, but often people breathe incorrectly.", "\"We're conditioned to hold in our belly all the time [to make ourselves look] beautiful \u2014 and we forget that actually doesn't support good breathing [and] it doesn't support our natural breath,\" she says.", "", "
Sarasvati Dawson says\u00a0breathing is key in yoga because it helps to slow down a busy mind.(Supplied:\u00a0Ksenia Belova)
", "When someone breathes correctly, their chest and belly should expand as they inhale as the diaphragm muscle pushes down and the belly rises.", "\"Then as we exhale, the navel draws back, the rib cage draws in, and that chest cavity becomes smaller,\" she explains.", "Breathing through the mouth is another bad habit, she says.", "\"Ideally, we breathe through our nose, because the nose is designed to filter, moisten and warm [the air], so there's less of a shock when the air gets to the lungs,\" she says.", "Breathing correctly has additional benefits like helping to improve posture and de-stress,\u00a0Ms Dawson says.", "\"[Having] tight muscles across the front of your chest, feeling stressed, these things all restrict our breathing,\" she says.", "Focusing on a long, slow exhalation can\u00a0help people de-stress and\u00a0uncover their natural breath, she explains.", "\"It's part of the strategy of getting out of the busy mind so that we can just be a bit steadier, a bit more focused [and]\u00a0a bit more present with our life.\""]
